Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Pancreaticojejunostomy and Pancreaticogastrostomy in High-Risk Postoperative Pancreatic Fistula Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: randomized controlled trial spanned from July 12, 2017, to March 15, 2019

Participants.evidence: Adults undergoing elective pancreaticoduodenectomy with a high fistula risk score (7-10) were randomized to PJ or PG.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether pancreaticojejunostomy (PJ) or pancreaticogastrostomy (PG), both with externalized transanastomotic stent, is superior in reducing POPF incidence.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was POPF incidence, assessed postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization used a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 604 screened, 72 were randomized (36 to PJ, 36 to PG).

Number_Analysed.evidence: 72 were randomized (36 to PJ, 36 to PG).

Result_Outcome.evidence: POPF incidence was not significantly different (PJ: 38.9%, PG: 50.0%; P = .48).

Harms.evidence: PG was associated with higher Clavien-Dindo grade 3 or higher morbidity (47.2% vs 22.2%; P = .047).
